THE NEWS..LETTER
Vol. XIV. No. 29.
SWARTHMORE
WINS AGAIN
This Time the Hopkins Alumni
Team Go Down to Defeat at
the Hands of the Fast Intercollegiate Champions.
In a hard-fought game the Swarthmore lacrosse team defeated the Hopkins Alumni twelve, 6 to 4, last Saturday afternoon at Homewood. The
victory of the visitors is all the more
creditable for them, as they played
without Bob Hall, their captain, and
several other of their regular players.
The maroon and white players ran
rings 'round the Hopkins veterans,but
they have not had the experience of
the alumni and did not know the fine
points of the game as well. If Hopkins had made its shots for goal in
the same ratio as the Swarthmore
players, the alumni would have won.
as they had at least twice as many
chances to shoot. Most of the shots
went wide of the goal, and so it was
not because Atkinson played a better game before the net for Swarthmore than "Bock" Blanck did for
Hopkins that the game was lost.
All the players on the Swarthmore
team were fast. They went after tne
ball with a rush that usually enabled
them to get it. The winners' system
of play was different from the Hopkins system. They would carry the
ball into the vicinity of the Hopkins
goal, and then pass it about until
they had an extra man before attempting to shoot. The local players
would carry the ball down the field,
and by some quick dodging or passing would try to get an opportunity
to shoot.
Captain Roberts' place was ably
filled by White. White played like
a veteran, and his stick-work was not
surpassed by any player on either
team. Collins led in shooting goals
and made three of the six Swarthmore tallies.
The alumni, with one or two exceptions, played a very good game.
If they had only had Henry Frank
playing On the close attack, they probably would have won. Alan Dill, the
'05 'varsity captain, showed up very
well. This is the first time he has
played ths season, and while his work
was very good he appeared, nevertheless, to be taking things easy. Dr.
Abercrombie was in fine form. He
is about the most accurate goal shooter on the team, and his teammates
should have passed the ball to him oftener than they did.
Collins shot the first goal after

IMPORTANT LECTURE
Course On Illuminating Engineering Next Year — Ames
Whitehead and Watson Among
the Speakers.
One of the most important courses
of lectures ever offered by this University will be given in the academic
year 1910-1911 on the Science and
Art of Illuminating Engineering.
The lectures will be thirty-six in
number and have three objects: "(I)
to indicate the proper coordination of
those arts and sciences which constitute illuminating engineering; (2) to
furnish a condensed outline of study
suitable for elaboration into an undergraduate course for introduction
into the curricula of undergraduate
technical schools; and (3) to give
practicing engineers an opportunity
to obtain a conception of the science
of illuminating engineering as a
whole."
"The lectures will be given under
the joint auspices of the University
and the Illuminating Engineering Society. The subjects and the scope of
the lectures have been proposed by
the society and approved by the University. The lecturers have been invited by the University upon the advice of the Society."
Prof. Ames will give the first series of lectures in the course. He
will deliver three lectures on "The
Physical Basis of the Production of
Light." Dr. Whitehead will give
two lectures on the "Generation and
Distribution of Electricity with Special Reference to Lighting." And
Dr. Watson will give one lecture on
the "Psychologcal Aspects of Illuminating Engineering."
Full particulars concerning the
course are given in a printed circular which may be obtained from Mr.
Ball, the Registrar, or from Prof.
Ames.
ATTENDED CONFERENCE
Prof. W. W. Willoughby and Mr.
L. B. Bobbitt returned last Friday
from Lake Mohonk, N. Y., where, in
company with a number of distinguished Baltimoreans, they attended
the sixteenth annual conference on
Arbitration. Mr. Bobbitt, it will be
remembered, was recently awarded
the prize offered by the conference
for the best essay on International
Arbitraton.
Dog fanciers of the University of
Pennsylvania have farmed a kennel
club.

THE NEWS-LETTER, May 3o, 1910.
COMMUNICATIONS
(The News-Letter will be glad to
publish communications from members of the University on topics of
the day. Manuscript should be endorsed with the writer's name, which
however will not be used unless the
Manuscript is signed. The Alumni
especially are urged to make use of
this column.)
To the Editor of The News-Letter.
Dear Sir:
• Apropos the ending of the lacrosse
season, I am venturing to suggest
that another year the scheme of the
Inter-Lacrosse League be abandoned,
and the former system of interclass
teams be reverted to. Any one wno
has watched the progress of the
league can plainly see, that while it
has perhaps increased the interest in
lacrosse at Mt. Washington and the
City College, there has not been much
interest in it at Hopkins. In fact, I
believe, one or two games were forfeited by Hopkins because not enough
men showed up to make up the team.
Compare this with the rivalry that
existed last year between the sophomore and freshman class teams. Every one was trying for the class
teams; men worked hard to make the
teams and practiced regularly. In
fact, each team had four or five substitutes. It was a question of class
rivalry; the sophomores were not going to be downed by the freshmen;
and the freshmen were eager to defeat the sophomores. But what do
men at Hopkins care about the City
College or the Mt. Washington
juniors. Very little in comparison
with the feeling, rivalry, and spirit
that exists between classes. Everyone knows that the Varsity team this
year consisted mainly of men who
gained their experience on the class
teams. Could the nucleus of a 'varsity team come from the team that
represented Hopkins in the lacrosse
league this year?
Therefore if the object of the 1903
team, in offering the prizes, was to
stimulate, encourage, and develop lacrosse at Hopkins, it might seem advisable that the old scheme of interclass lacrosse games be revived.

ENGLISH
COURSES
NEXT SESSION

FOR

Dr. Greene made the following
announcement last week in regard to
the English courses for next session.
The English Literature courses of
the University are so arranged as to
cov•tr the entire field of English Literature in three years. It is often
asked whether these courses must be
taken in any fixed order. While not
imperative, it is none the less desirable to pursue them in the order in
which they are numbered. For the
coming year the courses numbered
5 and 6 will be given by Mr. Myers,
in place of Prof. Browne. This is the
first time in some years that the Anglo-Saxon course (English Literature
6) has been offered to undergraduates; but it is intended to make it
hereafter a course especially for seniors, although open to members of
other classes.
The importance of the courses in
English Composition deserves emphasis. The department is directing
especial efforts to this work, to prevent the graduation of men who are
illiterate in the sense that they cannot write and speak good English.
Many who possess the degree of A.
B. are incapable of writing a creditable letter; this is not the case with
Hopkins graduates, however, and every effort is being put forth to continue and improve the past record.
The impression that there is a certain
discredit attached to membership in
English Composition ra is entirely
wrong. This course should be regarded as an opportunity and not as
a penalty. For men who desire to secure still more training in composition, the higher courses offer additional opportunities. The course in
description and narration is of a
somewhat literary character, and appeals to the exceptional student. The
training in exposition and argument,
on the other hand, is in most cases
more useful, and is of value in later
life to men in scientific work as well
as in other fields. This latter course
should properly be followed in the
senior year; Public Speaking 2 covers
somewhat the same ground for the
juniors.

SWARTHMORE
WINS AGAIN
This Time the Hopkins Alumni
Team Go Down to Defeat at
the Hands of the Fast Intercollegiate Champions.
In a hard-fought game the Swarthmore lacrosse team defeated the Hopkins Alumni twelve, 6 to 4, last Saturday afternoon at Homewood. The
victory of the visitors is all the more
creditable for them, as they played
without Bob Hall, their captain, and
several other of their regular players.
The maroon and white players ran
rings 'round the Hopkins veterans,but
they have not had the experience of
the alumni and did not know the fine
points of the game as well. If Hopkins had made its shots for goal in
the same ratio as the Swarthmore
players, the alumni would have won.
as they had at least twice as many
chances to shoot. Most of the shots
went wide of the goal, and so it was
not because Atkinson played a better game before the net for Swarthmore than "Bock" Blanck did for
Hopkins that the game was lost.
All the players on the Swarthmore
team were fast. They went after tne
ball with a rush that usually enabled
them to get it. The winners' system
of play was different from the Hopkins system. They would carry the
ball into the vicinity of the Hopkins
goal, and then pass it about until
they had an extra man before attempting to shoot. The local players
would carry the ball down the field,
and by some quick dodging or passing would try to get an opportunity
to shoot.
Captain Roberts' place was ably
filled by White. White played like
a veteran, and his stick-work was not
surpassed by any player on either
team. Collins led in shooting goals
and made three of the six Swarthmore tallies.
The alumni, with one or two exceptions, played a very good game.
If they had only had Henry Frank
playing On the close attack, they probably would have won. Alan Dill, the
'05 'varsity captain, showed up very
well. This is the first time he has
played ths season, and while his work
was very good he appeared, nevertheless, to be taking things easy. Dr.
Abercrombie was in fine form. He
is about the most accurate goal shooter on the team, and his teammates
should have passed the ball to him oftener than they did.
Collins shot the first goal after

IMPORTANT LECTURE
Course On Illuminating Engineering Next Year — Ames
Whitehead and Watson Among
the Speakers.
One of the most important courses
of lectures ever offered by this University will be given in the academic
year 1910-1911 on the Science and
Art of Illuminating Engineering.
The lectures will be thirty-six in
number and have three objects: "(I)
to indicate the proper coordination of
those arts and sciences which constitute illuminating engineering; (2) to
furnish a condensed outline of study
suitable for elaboration into an undergraduate course for introduction
into the curricula of undergraduate
technical schools; and (3) to give
practicing engineers an opportunity
to obtain a conception of the science
of illuminating engineering as a
whole."
"The lectures will be given under
the joint auspices of the University
and the Illuminating Engineering Society. The subjects and the scope of
the lectures have been proposed by
the society and approved by the University. The lecturers have been invited by the University upon the advice of the Society."
Prof. Ames will give the first series of lectures in the course. He
will deliver three lectures on "The
Physical Basis of the Production of
Light." Dr. Whitehead will give
two lectures on the "Generation and
Distribution of Electricity with Special Reference to Lighting." And
Dr. Watson will give one lecture on
the "Psychologcal Aspects of Illuminating Engineering."
Full particulars concerning the
course are given in a printed circular which may be obtained from Mr.
Ball, the Registrar, or from Prof.
Ames.
ATTENDED CONFERENCE
Prof. W. W. Willoughby and Mr.
L. B. Bobbitt returned last Friday
from Lake Mohonk, N. Y., where, in
company with a number of distinguished Baltimoreans, they attended
the sixteenth annual conference on
Arbitration. Mr. Bobbitt, it will be
remembered, was recently awarded
the prize offered by the conference
for the best essay on International
Arbitraton.

Pennsylvania have farmed a kennel
club.

the day. Manuscript should be endorsed with the writer's name, which

Manuscript is signed. The Alumni
especially are urged to make use of

To the Editor of The News-Letter.
Dear Sir:
• Apropos the ending of the lacrosse
season, I am venturing to suggest
that another year the scheme of the
Inter-Lacrosse League be abandoned,
and the former system of interclass
teams be reverted to. Any one wno
has watched the progress of the
league can plainly see, that while it
has perhaps increased the interest in
lacrosse at Mt. Washington and the
City College, there has not been much
interest in it at Hopkins. In fact, I
believe, one or two games were forfeited by Hopkins because not enough
men showed up to make up the team.
Compare this with the rivalry that
existed last year between the sophomore and freshman class teams. Every one was trying for the class
teams; men worked hard to make the
teams and practiced regularly. In
fact, each team had four or five substitutes. It was a question of class
rivalry; the sophomores were not going to be downed by the freshmen;
and the freshmen were eager to defeat the sophomores. But what do
men at Hopkins care about the City
College or the Mt. Washington
juniors. Very little in comparison
with the feeling, rivalry, and spirit
that exists between classes. Everyone knows that the Varsity team this
year consisted mainly of men who
gained their experience on the class
teams. Could the nucleus of a 'varsity team come from the team that
represented Hopkins in the lacrosse
league this year?
Therefore if the object of the 1903
team, in offering the prizes, was to
stimulate, encourage, and develop lacrosse at Hopkins, it might seem advisable that the old scheme of interclass lacrosse games be revived.

ENGLISH
COURSES
NEXT SESSION

FOR

Dr. Greene made the following
announcement last week in regard to
the English courses for next session.
The English Literature courses of
the University are so arranged as to
cov•tr the entire field of English Literature in three years. It is often
asked whether these courses must be
taken in any fixed order. While not
imperative, it is none the less desirable to pursue them in the order in
which they are numbered. For the
coming year the courses numbered
5 and 6 will be given by Mr. Myers,
in place of Prof. Browne. This is the
first time in some years that the Anglo-Saxon course (English Literature
6) has been offered to undergraduates; but it is intended to make it
hereafter a course especially for seniors, although open to members of
other classes.
The importance of the courses in
English Composition deserves emphasis. The department is directing
especial efforts to this work, to prevent the graduation of men who are
illiterate in the sense that they cannot write and speak good English.
Many who possess the degree of A.
B. are incapable of writing a creditable letter; this is not the case with
Hopkins graduates, however, and every effort is being put forth to continue and improve the past record.
The impression that there is a certain
discredit attached to membership in
English Composition ra is entirely
wrong. This course should be regarded as an opportunity and not as
a penalty. For men who desire to secure still more training in composition, the higher courses offer additional opportunities. The course in
description and narration is of a
somewhat literary character, and appeals to the exceptional student. The
training in exposition and argument,
on the other hand, is in most cases
more useful, and is of value in later
life to men in scientific work as well
as in other fields. This latter course
should properly be followed in the
senior year; Public Speaking 2 covers
somewhat the same ground for the
juniors.
